awd_titl_txt: Modeling the physics of gas removal and star formation quenching in Local Group satellite galaxies with next-generation simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  Jenna Samuel is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the University of Texas.  Samuel will perform detailed computer simulations of the Milky Way (MW) and Andromeda galaxies.  Results from this study will allow astronomers to understand how gas is removed and star formation quenched in galaxies.   For the education component of this project, Samuel will develop a seminar series and conduct research mentorship activities to increase the retention of students of color in the sciences.

This project will conduct and benchmark exceedingly high-resolution cosmological simulations of MW-like halo environments. It will produce the first numerically converged models of stellar feedback and ram pressure stripping in satellite dwarf galaxies, and it will provide a comprehensive theoretical basis for determining (1) what caused the MW satellite galaxies to quench so completely, (2) whether the MW halo environment is typical of nearby analogs, and (3) whether MW satellites are unique in their formation history.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project has contributed significantly to our understanding of satellite galaxy quenching, providing novel insights into galaxy evolution while fostering a productive, student-centered research environment. The two published papers from this project explore how environmental factors, particularly ram pressure and group preprocessing, regulate star formation in satellite galaxies around the Milky Way and Andromeda. Through detailed simulations, the project demonstrated for the first time the effects of group accretion on satellite galaxies, revealing that the high quiescent fraction of satellites in the Local Group may be due, in part, to the accretion of galaxy groups rather than isolated galaxies. Additionally, the project quantified the role of ram pressure in the quenching process, unveiling new findings about the effects of impulsive and anisotropic ram pressure in low-mass galaxy environments. This research not only enhances our understanding of satellite galaxy evolution but also lays the groundwork for future studies that could incorporate these findings into observational predictions, such as the formation of ultra-diffuse galaxies.

The broader impacts of the project are equally significant, both for the scientific community and for educational outreach. Mentoring three undergraduate students in particular has helped foster the next generation of researchers, while the development of an in-preparation paper on tidal disruption promises to further advance the field. Beyond research, the fellowship has promoted collaborative and educational initiatives, including the creation of a seminar series aimed at training UT Austin graduate students in astronomical observing and a mentor training seminar for the Texas Astronomy Undergraduate Research experience for Under-represented Students (TAURUS). Furthermore, the commissioning of educational infographics and the revitalization of the NSF astronomy and astrophysics postdoctoral fellows' website as part of the fellowship have made complex astrophysical concepts and the long history of the fellows more accessible to the public. These efforts underscore the project’s commitment to broader societal engagement, ensuring that the scientific advancements made during the fellowship extend beyond the academic community.


 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Jenna Samuel
